name: Lucas–Wieferich prime
rephrased: A Lucas–Wieferich prime is a prime number that satisfies a specific condition related to Lucas sequences and is analogous to the concept of a Wieferich prime.
implication_form: If a prime satisfies the Lucas–Wieferich condition, then it is a Lucas–Wieferich prime.
posed_by: Arthur Wieferich (in the context of Fermat's Last Theorem, though the specific Lucas–Wieferich concept may have been formalized later)
explained: A Wieferich prime is a prime number p such that p² divides 2^{p-1} - 1. This condition is stronger than Fermat's Little Theorem, which states that for any odd prime p, p divides 2^{p-1} - 1. Wieferich primes were first described by Arthur Wieferich in 1909 in works pertaining to Fermat's Last Theorem. There are only two known Wieferich primes: 1093 and 3511.
